work_with_me_opening:
For Colleagues

What I bring to the table

More often than not, I am usually the technical guy in the project, responsible for the data analysis, model development, and producing super cool graphs and tables. It is worth mentioning that I am an OK-ish writer but always happy to write the technical section of the paper. If I may, my main selling point in the academic realm is the time to deliver as I am aiming to keep a very fast-paced project delivery while ensuring the highest level of quality.

What I am looking for in an academic project

I believe that researchers should agree in advance about how a project is managed and operated. Hence, my usual main points of concern:
1) Time to deliver - once we agree on a time to deliver something, by anyone on the team, it should be ready on time or everyone should get an update as soon as possible about the drift from plans. If you delay time and time again, I will take my stuff and leave.
2) Credit distribution - we will agree on the author list in advance and set up a metric to re-visit the order at the end, making sure everyone gets his real credit and not playing games or performing political tricks.
3) Paper submission payments (i.e., APC) - If I have money, I will gladly pay. However, we need to agree on the budget limit for each paper in advance.
4) Working with your students - I enjoy the company of students like the other guy. Nonetheless, if you work with me, I expect to work with you - not your (amazing) student(s). It is wonderful if your students participate in the project but this does not mean you can disappear for weeks each time or not take personal responsibility on the project. This means that if the student does not deliver, I am expecting you to handle and fix this.
5) Submission blocking - I know this is an unpleasant topic, but let's quickly discuss it... If I have done a lot of work to produce a paper and someone is blocking the submission due to any reason, I am leaving the decision to the leading PI - which we will agree on at the beginning of the project. All team members will agree in advance who is the leading PI before the project starts. In the moment of truth, if a team member refuses to accept the leading PI's decision, I promise to provide an unproportional response.
6) Honesty - research is very dynamic and shit happens. We all should talk about stuff and overcome them. Hence, I do not check the results of my colleagues (or their students) but I expect them to be 100 percent sure about the credibility and honesty of the results they report.

On the happy side, I am looking for high-impact studies that have real-world implications, if possible.

How shall we start?

Just send over an email - I promise to answer as soon as possible. It would be great if you could outline the main points of the research and pinpoint your needs. If you have difficulties doing so, no worries - we can discuss it together and come up with something together.

For Students

Purpose

It is important to make an informed decision when choosing a research mentor. This webpage will help you to understand how I (currently) view my role as a mentor as well as the expectations that I have for members of our team. This webpage is under constant review and revision, as it should be since it is a constant work in progress. Moreover, these guidelines are a bit generic as each person’s mentorship and training needs are unique.

Open research questions

1) Socio-economic tasks - solving analytically, numerically, or using simulation on a wide range of social, government, and economic tasks.
2) Developing data-driven personalized clinical treatment protocols. In particular, I prefer cancer and autoimmune diseases (such as diabetes).
3) Epidemiological dynamics modeling, forecasting, and understanding. In particular, in integration with other disciplines such as economy, governance, business management, biology, clinical, etc.
4) I am a big fan of anything cool that you can simulate and use AI for decision-making, so you can be creative.
*) I really enjoy novel ideas from students, so please read my latest work and come up with your ideas!

Your mentorship network

It is important to recognize that I am not an expert in all areas in which you wish to receive mentorship. However, I do consider it my responsibility to ensure that when I cannot meet your needs in a specific area we work together to connect you with a mentor that can. I encourage you to seek out their expertise and advice. You should not view me as the person central to your mentoring network since you are the central person in your mentoring network. Cultivating a thriving mentoring network is an important part of your research training and I will work to help you get started and identify your specific needs and how those needs can be met.

My mentorship commitment to you when you join the team

1) At the bare minimum, we will have a weekly 1:1 meeting. I will do my best to never cancel this meeting if not absolutely necessary. If that happens, the meeting will be rescheduled for as soon as possible. You can cancel this meeting whenever you like. It is your time.

2) Our 1:1 agenda by default will include discussions about your wellness, readiness, obstacles, recognition, and feedback from me. However, you should be added to the meeting invite for any agenda you would like to have. This is important so we remember important topics, but you are free to use the time for whatever is on your mind.

3) When I schedule a meeting with you, I will always tell you what the meeting will be about when it is scheduled.

4) News or announcements that significantly impact you or your work will always come from me directly in a 1:1 meeting. I will hold dear your privacy.

5) You will always get feedback from me when it is fresh. You will never get feedback from me when we discuss your overall performance that will be a surprise. We will always try to talk about small issues that come up so they do not turn into big issues.

6) I trust you to manage your own time. You don’t need to clear with me in advance your time. You do not need to ask my permission to attend important appointments during business hours.

7) Your work gets done your way. My focus is on outcomes, not output. Once we are clear on where we need to go, how you get there is up to you, with support from me and your committee as required.

8) A team is strongest when it is working together, looking after each other, and taking care of one another. Please look to your left and to your right for opportunities to help other members of our team. Please ask for help when you need it. Nobody works alone.

9) I trust you to skip over me and talk to other colleagues (like your committee members/mentors) about anything you feel is relevant. You do not need to clear it with me in advance.

10) I will attribute credit appropriately to you. I will never exaggerate my own role or minimize your contribution. I will be especially certain to nail down attribution when people want to hear about our accomplishments.

Publishing

In general, if a paper is written regarding a part of your research project and you conducted the research and prepared the manuscript you will be named as the first author. This policy is the same for all trainees. If other members of the team were involved in the work, they would also be listed as authors based on their contributions or alphabetically if their contributions were equal. No manuscripts will be submitted to any journal, conference, etc. without the prior review and consent of all co-authors (this includes student co-authors).

Conflict resolution

I expect that if you are having a problem with someone else on the team you will begin by approaching that person to discuss the problem openly. If the problem is not resolved to your satisfaction, then you are free to speak to me about the problem and I can help to mediate a remedy. If your problem is with me, please schedule an appointment so that we can discuss your concerns and try to remedy the problem. If you keep the problem to yourself there is no way for me to know that you are unhappy with the way things are going and, in my experience, most problems are easily remedied with an open discussion.


Team members

The best way to know if you want to work with me is to ask individuals that already made this decision. You can (and should) approach them directly so they can tell you the truth with all the pros and cons. I suggest mixing current and alumni to get the bigger picture. You can checkout the Lab page on this site for more infomation.

How to join

Joining the lab is a two-phase processes. First, you need to make sure you can take me as an academic advisor in the first place. Please talk with the relevant personnel in the university to make sure this is indeed the case. I will not do it for you. Second, send over an email with a short introduction about yourself, your research desires, and why you think I am the best advisor for the task (not the other way around). I promise to answer as soon as possible. If I do not, please follow this algorithm: If less than 5 business days have passed - wait. If more than 5 business days and this is the first time, write another polite email. If 5 business days have passed from your second email, CC the head of the department and use a sad smiley in the title of the email. If I still do not answer after 5 more business days, I am probably dead and you are expected to find out where is my office and bring flowers.


I would like to thank Dr. Amy Greer for the idea for this page. Some of its content is an adaptation of her text.

projects.name: Understanding pandemic spread and optimizing resource allocation to control it
projects.description: This line of projects focuses on developing mathematical models and simulations to predict the spread of infectious diseases - mainly using extended spatio-temporal SIR models with agent-based simulation and decision making using RL. By leveraging these models, we aim to create efficient strategies for resource allocation, ensuring optimal control and mitigation of pandemics.

projects.name: A biologically-informed and data-driven approach to scientometrics
projects.description: This research line leverages biological principles and advanced data analytics to evaluate and understand scientific research impact and trends. By integrating these approaches, we aim to develop more accurate and insightful metrics for assessing scientific contributions and guiding future research directions.

projects.name: Understanding animals' behavior and improving their wellness using AI
projects.description: By analyzing behavioral and sensorial data, we seek to gain deeper insights into animal health and habits, enabling the development of advanced strategies for monitoring, diagnosing, and improving their overall wellness. This approach supports more effective and compassionate care practices for animals. For this line of work, we closely work with the Tech4animal lab from University of Haifa.

projects.name: Individual and community personalized medicine using AI
projects.description: This initiative aims to harness the power of artificial intelligence (AI) to tailor medical treatments to individual patients and improve medical resource allocation for specific communities. By analyzing vast amounts of medical data, from our clinical partners, we strive to develop personalized treatment protocols that improve health outcomes and enhance the efficacy of medical interventions.

projects.name: The Science of Symbolic Regression
projects.description: In this line of work, which is the (third) Ph.D. of Dr. Assaf Shmual, we are investigating the usage of symbolic regression as a tool with machine learning and deep learning tools in solving real-wolrd problems.

projects.name: Machine Learning Approaches to Predict and Detect Early-onset of Digital Dermatitis in Dairy Cows using Sensor Data
projects.description: Digital dermatitis is a common foot disease that can cause lameness, decreased milk production and decreased fertility in cows. Its prediction and early detection can positive impact welfare and economic value in dairy cow industry. This study develops machine learning models for easlyonset detection and prediction of digital dermatitis (DD) based on behavior data obtained from a commonly used commercial sensor monitoring system. We present a model for DD detection on day 0 (appearance of signs) with accuracy 79%, and a model for prediction of DD 2 days prior to appearance of signs with accuracy 64%.

projects.name: Socio-Demographic Indicators for Hospitalization Duration of Patients with Borderline Personality Disorder: A Retrospective Study
projects.description: Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) is a complex psychopathology associated with intense emotional instability and high service utilization rates. While certain socio-demographic factors have been linked to an increased risk of BPD, their relation to hospitalization duration remains unclear. This retrospective study analyzed 1077 hospitalization records of 200 BPD-diagnosed patients. Patients' key socio-demographic characteristics were examined as to their potential relationship with the patients' hospitalization duration.  Patients' gender, age, education level, employment and marital statuses, and living arrangement were statistically significantly linked with patients' hospitalization duration. Additionally, the hospitalization index and previous hospitalization duration were also statistically associated with patients' hospitalization duration. Patients' expected hospitalization duration at admission varies significantly based, in part, on their socio-demographics. In order to prevent potentially unnecessary prolonged and regressive hospitalizations, an estimation of the expected hospitalization duration should be explicitly considered.

projects.name: The Scientometrics and Reciprocality Underlying Co-Authorship Panels in Google Scholar Profiles
projects.description: Online academic profiles are used by scholars to reflect a desired image to their online audience. In Google Scholar,  scholars can select a subset of co-authors for presentation in a central location on their profile using a social feature called the Co-authroship panel. In this work, we examine whether scientometrics and reciprocality can explain the observed selections. To this end, we scrape and thoroughly analyze a novel set of 120,000 Google Scholar profiles, ranging across four disciplines and various academic institutions. Our results suggest that scholars tend to favor co-authors with higher scientometrics over others for inclusion in their co-authorship panels. Interestingly, as one’s own scientometrics are higher, the tendency to include co-authors with high scientometrics is diminishing. Furthermore, we find that reciprocality is central in explaining scholars' selections.

projects.name: The Family Tree Graph as a Predictor of the Family Members' Satisfaction with One Another
projects.description: Individuals' satisfaction with their nuclear and extended family plays a critical role in individuals everyday life. Thus, a better understanding of the features that determine one's satisfaction with her family can open the door to the design of better sociological policies. To this end, this study examines the relationship between the family tree graph and family members' satisfaction with their nuclear and extended family. We collected data from 486 families which included a family tree graph and family members' satisfaction with each other. We obtain a model that is able to explain 75% of the family members' satisfaction with one another. We found three indicators for more satisfied families. First, larger families, on average, have more satisfied members. Moreover, families with kids from the same parents - i.e., without step-siblings also express more satisfaction from both their siblings and parents when the children are already adults. Lastly, the average satisfaction of the family's oldest alive generation has a positive linear and non-linear correlation with the satisfaction of the entire extended family.

projects.name: Temporal Graphs Anomaly Emergence Detection: Benchmarking For Social Media Interactions
projects.description: Temporal graphs have become an essential tool for analyzing complex dynamic systems with multiple agents. Detecting anomalies in temporal graphs is crucial for various applications, including identifying emerging trends, monitoring network security, understanding social dynamics, tracking disease outbreaks, and understanding financial dynamics. In this paper, we present a comprehensive benchmarking study that compares 12 data-driven methods for anomaly detection in temporal graphs. We conduct experiments on two temporal graphs extracted from Twitter and Facebook, aiming to identify anomalies in group interactions. Surprisingly, our study reveals an unclear pattern regarding the best method for such tasks, highlighting the complexity and challenges involved in anomaly emergence detection in large and dynamic systems. The results underscore the need for further research and innovative approaches to effectively detect emerging anomalies in dynamic systems represented as temporal graphs.

projects.name: Nash and Trading Equilibria in a Public Good Economy with Finite Number of Private and Public Goods and Asymmetrical Agents
projects.description: Two of the common equilibrium concepts used in the theory of public goods are the Nash and Lindahl equilibria. Although the Nash equilibrium outcome is conceptually appealing, it is not Pareto efficient. Nonetheless, while the Lindahl allocation is Pareto efficient, it does not Pareto dominate the Nash allocation. Scholars have proposed Pareto efficient allocations that are preferable to the Nash equilibrium bundle while exploiting the Pareto efficient properties of the Lindahl equilibrium. However, these models are always restricted. In this paper, we consider an extension of one of these models - the Trading model - to a finite number of private and public goods with asymmetric agents and prove the existence and uniqueness of a Pareto efficient Trading allocation based on personalized Lindahl prices, which Pareto dominates the unique Nash allocation in the economy. We demonstrate the proposed model for a social healthcare service funding program using computer simulation.

projects.name: Can We Mathematically Spot Possible Manipulation of Results in Research Manuscripts Using Benford's Law?
projects.description: The reproducibility of academic research has long been a persistent issue, contradicting one of the fundamental principles of science. What is even more concerning is the increasing number of false claims found in academic manuscripts recently, casting doubt on the validity of reported results. In this paper, we utilize an adaptive version of Benford's law, a statistical phenomenon that describes the distribution of leading digits in naturally occurring datasets, to identify potential manipulation of results in research manuscripts, solely using the aggregated data presented in those manuscripts. Our methodology applies the principles of Benford's law to commonly employed analyses in academic manuscripts, thus, reducing the need for the raw data itself. To validate our approach, we employed 100 open-source datasets and successfully predicted 79% of them accurately using our rules. Additionally, we analyzed 100 manuscripts published in the last two years across ten prominent economic journals, with ten manuscripts randomly sampled from each journal. Our analysis predicted a 3% occurrence of result manipulation with a 96% confidence level. Our findings uncover disturbing inconsistencies in recent studies and offer a semi-automatic method for their detection.

projects.name: Spatio-Temporal Model Of Multi-Pathogen Disease Dynamics for Pigeons Vising Dairy Farms
projects.description: Zoonotic disease transmission between animals and humans is a growing risk and the agricultural context as a likely point of transition. Understanding the dynamics of disease spread within wildlife, that may connect spatially isolated farms, and livestock that are often at high local densities facilitating spread within a farm is crucial for mitigating these risks. Specifically, the interactions between pigeons and cows clustered in dairy farms can lead to significant disease transmission, economic losses for farmers, and food shortages affecting animal, livestock, and human populations. In this paper, we propose a novel spatio-temporal multi-pathogen model based on the Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered-Dead (SEIRD) framework with continuous spatial movement. Our model accounts for both within-species and cross-species transmission of pathogens, as well as the exploratory-expository movement dynamics of pigeons, which play a critical role in the spread of infections. We implemented the proposed model as a computer program using the agent-based simulation approach. We explore different biologically-realistic scenarios using biologically-relevant setups, evaluating the effect of various parameters on the epidemic spread. Namely, we show that the heterogeneity of the pigeons' movement dynamics has only a relatively minor effect on the disease spread. In addition, pigeons' reduced movement behavior due to being infected with pathogens shows to have a positive linear correlation to the average reproduction number of the disease.

projects.name: How Colaborations Influance Writting Style
projects.description: In this research, we anaylzed using a time-dependent graph model and several deep learning based natural language processing models the dynamics of writting style in academic texts, focusing on papers from the exact science domain from the DBLP dataset.

projects.name: Predicting the locaiton of metastates of lung cancer using the location of the original location
projects.description: We develop a novel bio-clinical model with compuer vision component to predict the location of lung cancer metastates.

projects.name: The Economical-Epidemiological Management Of The Coffee Trees Rust Pandemic
projects.description: In this research, we provide the most realistic and accurate coffee rust pandemic model and simulation that takes into consideration the economic dynamics. We used our model on historical data from Colombia.

projects.name: Trust and Work Engagement in Law Enforcement: The case of Brazil
projects.description: I promise to add later

projects.name: Alexi's Master (1) - A Security Games Inspired Approach for Distributed Controlling Of Pandemic Spread
projects.description: In this research, we propose a novel Pandemic Intervention Policy (PIP) that relies on the strategic deployment of Inspection Units (IUs). These IUs are allocated in the environment, represented as a graph, and sample individuals who pass through the same node. If a sampled individual is identified as infected, she is extracted from the environment until she recovers (or dies).

projects.name: Alexi's Master (2) - The Trade-off Between Energy Consumption and Airborne Pandemic Control Using Air-Ventilation Systems
projects.description: We measured the energetic consumption and air ventilation capabilities of central air-ventilation fresh air system, anti-bacterial indoor device, and open window in inpatient rooms, classrooms, and conference rooms. This way, we will find the Parto-optimal trade-off between energy consumption and pandemic spread.

projects.name: Alexi's Master (3) - A Security Games For Pandemic Spread
projects.description: We extend the previous work - not sure how at this point...

projects.name: Alexi's Master (4) - Multi-Species Prey-Predator Dynamics During a Multi-Strain Pandemic
projects.description: We investigate the ecosystem's sensitivity during a multi-strain pandemic for several properties in syntactic cases. In addition, we used two real-world configurations to evaluate the influence of the inner-species and cross-species infection on the long-term ecosystem's stability, showing that cross-infection.

projects.name: Academic Co-authorship is a Risky Game
projects.description: Publication authorship is one of the main recognitions researchers obtain for their research. It is therefore paramount to have a robust and acceptable system in place that ensures fairness and due process for disputes. The current system largely relies on the integrity of researchers but often fails when disputes arise. The use of an unbiased, data-driven model could overcome this limitation. In this study, we developed the first game-theory-inspired model to explore the dynamics of co-authorship disputes. The results are alarming and suggest that the current academic practices are not fit for purpose. Worryingly, our model shows that the number of potential disputes increases as the number of authors participating in the research increases, which is the global trend.

projects.name: OMEGA
projects.description: We develop an algorithm to simulation pathogenic DNA sequences from healthy sequences.

projects.name: Bounding Pandemic Spread By Heat Spread
projects.description: We provide a theoretical upper boundery for the pandemic spread (SIR model) in the form of heat spread on an infection graph.

projects.name: Generic Approach For Mathematical Model of Multi-Strain Pandemics
projects.description: We propose a multi-strain epidimological model based on the SIR model and show several analytical properties of the model.

projects.name: Mathematical Model for the BCG-based Treatment Of Type 1 Diabetes
projects.description: We propose a BCG immunotherapy for the T1D and show numerical results for the mouse model.

projects.name: Assessing The Scientific Neglect Of Animal Species At Risk Of Extinction
projects.description: We provide a wide range litreture review of animal species and compute the neglection of the academic community to several of them.

projects.name: Advanced Muti-Mutation with Intervention Policies Pandemic Model
projects.description: We propose a multi-strain with several clinical and genotype dynamics epidimological model and numerically show its ability to predict the course of a pandemic in Israel.

projects.name: An Enhanced Pandemic Spread with Mutations SIVRI Model
projects.description: We extend the multi-strain model from the previous work, including more clinical processes, showing predictions for several countries.

projects.name: Evaluating Taxation Policies Outcomes In a Close and Supply-Demand Based Economy with Heterogeneous Population using Genetic Algorithms
projects.description: We developed a mathematical model and computer simulation for close economy supply-demand model to evaluate taxation policies.

projects.name: Socioeconomic Model for Work Engagement in the Public Sector
projects.description: Not avalible yet.

projects.name: A review of the behavioural changes and physiological adjustments of elasmobranchs and teleost's to ocean acidification with a focus on sharks
projects.description: A systematic overview of the litreture regarding marine life with focus on sharks.

projects.name: Comparison Of Pandemic Intervention Policies In Different Building Types Using Spatio-Temporal Model
projects.description: We are studing the pandemic spread indoor for several types of buildings based on extended SIR model

projects.name: Financing and Managing Epidemiological-Economic Crisis: The Reserve Model
projects.description: An economic taxation policy for handling future crisises with mathematical model and in silico experiments.

projects.name: A New Definition For Feature Selection Stability Analysis
projects.description: We propose a new definition for FS stability analysis and show how it outperform the classical metrics.

projects.name: Optimal Filter And Embedding Feature Selection Ensemble For Explainable Machine Learning Models
projects.description: We propose a meta-meta search algorithm for automatic machine learning, focusing on Filter and Embedded feature selection.

projects.name: The Influence Of Lockdown Due To Pandemic On The Population’s Mental Health
projects.description: We analyze historical data about the COVID-19 pandemic in Israel with epidimological, social, and mental health data.

projects.name: Stable Dataset Summarizing
projects.description: We propose a new algorithm to summarize datasets for faster analysis pipelines.

projects.name: High Resolution Mathematical Model for Airborne Pandemic Spread Indoors
projects.description: We investigate the influance of air circulation inside a room on the pandemic spread.

projects.name: A Better Prediction of the Non-Observed Economy in Israel
projects.description: A new (more stable) mathematical model for estimating the non-observable economy. An empirical analysis for Israel is conducted.

projects.name: Estimation of Non-Observed Economy Using Observed Economy and Partial Non-Observed Economy with Deep Learning
Estimating the damages of an unreported oil tanker spill using integrated physical-economic modeling: the Israel February 2021 marine and coastal petroleum contamination
An Algorithm to Optimize Explainability using Feature Ensembles
projects.description: A feature selection algorithms that uses iterative ensemble intersections given preformance and explainability metrics to obtain an optimal feature set.

projects.name: The Connection Between Associative Distance and Rumination in Hebrew Speaking Individuals
projects.description: Developing a machine learning model for words' associative distance (Hebrew). Based on this model, propusing new rumination test for clinical professionals.

projects.name: Predicting Acute Kidney Injury Following Open Partial Nephrectomy Treatment Using SAT-Pruned Explainable Machine Learning Model
projects.description: Developing an eXplanable AI to predict acute kidney injury (AKI) complications due to Partial Nephrectomy (PN) treatment.

projects.name: Sphera – A template for personal academic websites
projects.description: Sphera is a free open-source website template that will vastly improve the communication between lecturers and students. It will provide lecturers and professors with the tools to easily create a professional personal website that contains their research, courses and personal projects. We will study the user behaivor in personal acadmic websites and how to improve it using machine learning reccomendation system.

projects.name: Decision Tree Post-Pruning Without Loss Of Accuracy using the SAT-PP algorithm with An Empirical Evaluation on Clinical Data
projects.description: We propose a new Boolean satisfiability (SAT) based PP algorithm, SAT-PP algorithm, which reduces the tree size while preserving the accuracy of the unpruned tree, since in medical-related tasks, decreasing the model's performance is something we emphatically try to avoid where better training is not an option.

projects.name: Mathematical model for the early stage Type 1 Diabetes BCG-based Prevention Treatment
projects.description: Developing from scratch a new bio-clinical model for type 1 disbetes treatment using BCG in early stages of the diseases.

projects.name: A More Numerically Accurate Algorithm For Matrix Exponent
projects.description: we propose a novel highly accurate numerical algorithm for the matrix exponent (ME). The algorithm is based on approximating Putzler's algorithm by analytically solving the ODE based coefficients and approximating them.

projects.name: Improved Geometric Configuration for the Bladder Cancer BCG-based Immunotherapy Treatment Model
projects.description: We present an extension to the model proposed by Lazebnik et al. (2020) by improving the approximation of the bladder’s geometry from sphere-ring to ellipsoid-ring.

projects.name: Predicting the locaiton of metastates of lung cancer using the location of the primary tumor
projects.description: We develop a computer simulation in order to predict the locations of metastates in lung cancer.

projects.name: Simulating Street Level Birucrats Decision Making
projects.description: Not avalible yet.

projects.name: Machine translation from Russian to English for Academic Papers
projects.description: A dedicated ML model for machine translation from Russian to English for Academic papers.

projects.name: Computer Aided Functional Style Identification and Usage In Modern-Russian Texts
projects.description: A deep learning model for functional style classification in Russian and a software to help humans to perform functional style corrections in a text

projects.name: Novel Method to Analytically Obtain the Asymptotic Stable Equilibria States of Extended SIR-type Epidemiological Models
projects.description: We present a new analytical method to find the asymptotic stable equilibria states based on the Markov chain technique. We reveal this method on the SIR-type epidemiological model that we developed for viral diseases with long-term immunity memory pandemic.

projects.name: A Distinction of Three Online Learning Pedagogic Paradigms
projects.description: We studied three online pedagogic paradigm (Synchronous, Asynchronous, and Asynchronous with an audience) and their influence on the students learning process and achievements during an academic mathematics course that was conducted online.

projects.name: Pandemic Management by a Spatio-temporal Mathematical Model
projects.description: A spatio-temporal mathematical model based on the SIR model and graph-based spatial dynamics solved using distrebuted system methods, allowing to investigate several non-pharmaceutical intervention (NPI) policies to control the epidemic.

projects.name: Spatio-Temporal Influence of Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions Policies on Pandemic Dynamics and the Economy: The Case of COVID-19
projects.description: A spatio-temporal mathematical model with economic dynamics. We investigate the influance and find optimal non-pharmaceutical intervention (NPI) policies on the pandemic and the economy.

projects.name: PDE Based Geometry Model for BCG Immunotherapy of Bladder Cancer
projects.description: We present a model describing a BCG immunotherapy dynamic taking into consideration an approximation of the bladder’s geometry using PDE.

projects.name: Optimal Border Closure Policy and Tourism Flows During Epidemiological-Economic Crises: An Artificial Intelligence Approach.
projects.description: A epidemiological-economic simulation, allowing to investigate the influance of non-pharmaceutical intervention policies on international tourism during a pandemic.

projects.name: Pharmaceutical and Non-pharmaceutical Intervention Policies of a Multi-Sectoral Economic-Epidemiological Model
projects.description: A epidemiological-economic simulation, allowing to investigate the influance of non-pharmaceutical intervention policies on multi-sectoral economy in a local and international scale.

projects.name: Rivendell v.3 with explicit collaborative learning
projects.description: Improvments to the Rivendell search engine. Including collaborative learning. The development done on C# based dot net core 2

projects.name: Property-Value tagging tool as website
projects.description: Prodcution-ready (C# on dot net core 2) search engine.

projects.name: Rivendell v.2 with online learning search engine
projects.description: Prodcution-ready (C# on dot net core 2 with Angular 8) SaaS providing for taggers an easy to use Property-Value tagging GUI.
